qas.question: What happened to the Alpine orogenic belt that gave it the steep vertical peak?
Mont Blanc, the Matterhorn, and peaks in the Pennine Alps cosist of what?

answers.text: layers of rock from the various orogenies

qas.question: What are the common characteristics of the Alpine Orogenic Belt?

context: The core regions of the Alpine orogenic belt have been <a0_0>folded and fractured<a0_0/> in such a manner that erosion created the characteristic <a2_0>steep vertical peaks<a2_0/> of the Swiss Alps that rise seemingly straight out of the foreland areas. Peaks such as Mont Blanc, the Matterhorn, and high peaks in the Pennine Alps, the Briançonnais, and Hohe Tauern consist of <a1_0>layers of rock from the various orogenies<a1_0/> including exposures of basement rock.
